results.title: Makin' up!. The Most beautiful breasts in the world
results.creator_credit: Katja Von Garnier, Ewa Karlstrom and Vela-X Filmproduktion
results.brief_description: Makin’ Up! (1992, 54 mins.) is an endearing comedy that focuses on the friendship between two women, Frenzy (Katja Riemann), a cynical, independent cartoonist, and Maischa (Nina Kronjager), a nurse desperately trying to find Mr Right. When Maischa scores a date with a man she has been lusting after, Frenzy is reluctantly forced to entertain his friend for the night. Neither of these interactions turns out as they expected and while both women are forced to re-evaluate their attitudes to romantic love, they realise that while men come and go, their lasting friendship will always provide them with constant pleasure and emotional support. “Makin’ Up!” is peppered with laughs, never taking itself too seriously. It is characterised by strong writing, inventive direction, and a rare chemistry between the two main characters. “The Most Beautiful Breasts in the World” (1990, 15 mins. prods/dirs, Thomas Wobke, Rainer Kaufmann) is a frivolous fantasy about a businessman who unexpectedly finds he has acquired a pair of prominent breasts. Both films in German with English subtitles.

results.title: Makeshift solutions
results.brief_description: Sixth in a series of nine animated films on the history of western civilization. Looks at the rise of capitalism during the 19th century; examines the formation of trusts, cartels and monopolies; and discusses the use of cheap labour and cheap raw materials.
results.description: Sixth in a series of nine animated films on the history of western civilization. Looks at the rise of capitalism during the 19th century; examines the formation of trusts, cartels and monopolies; and discusses the use of cheap labour and cheap raw materials.

results.title: Makers of wine
results.brief_description: A survey of the Australian wine industry showing how wine is made, and some of the by-products which are produced in addition to excellent table wines. For wine grapes to grow well, soil and climate must be right; various types of soil are more suitable for some kinds of wine-grapes than others. In Australia, irrigation in the Murray Valley has helped the wine industry, for in many areas where wine is now produced, soil and general climate are suitable, but the rainfall is inadequate. Narrated by John Sherwood.

results.title: Make your senate vote count
results.brief_description: Bill Peach of ABC’s “This Day Tonight” explains how to vote correctly in a Senate election. In the last Senate election nearly half a million informal votes out of a possible 6 million, were cast and could not be counted. Tells the five simple steps to avoid mistakes.

results.title: Make way for ducklings
results.creator_credit: Morton Schindel and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: Animated story adapted from the book by Robert McClosky. Mr and Mrs Mallard are looking for a home. They finally choose a cosy place in the bushes beside a river in Boston, where their ducklings are hatched. One day Mrs Mallard takes her ducklings across to the park to meet Mr Mallard. Traffic is held up for them by friendly policemen.

results.title: Make up/SPFX
results.credit_line:
Edie Kurzer, Australia, 2020

Make-up box with make-up

Courtesy Lee-Anne Donnolley
results.brief_description: In the digital age it’s sometimes easy to overlook the physical crafts of filmmaking. Make-up and prosthetics are vital to the creation of characters in film, television and theatre - bringing werewolves, Terminators and planets full of apes to life.

constellations_other.name: Oscar-winning transformations and prosthetics
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores how craft help actors undergo award-winning transformations into iconic characters.

results.description: In the digital age it’s sometimes easy to overlook the physical crafts of filmmaking. Make-up and prosthetics are vital to the creation of characters in film, television and theatre - bringing werewolves, Terminators and planets full of apes to life. Despite not being celebrated at the Oscars until 1980, make-up and prosthetics have a long history in cinema. An outcry over The Elephant Man not being recognised at the 1980 Academy Awards led to the creation of a new category, which has seen Australian winners like Lesley Vanderwalt, Elka Wardega and Damian Martin being recognised for their work on Mad Max: Fury Road (2015).

results.title: Make It Right (A)
results.creator_credit: Inst of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies and Central and Northern Land Councils
results.brief_description: An impressionistic account of the Prime Minister, Bob Hawke’s, 1988 visit to the Barunga Festival in remote Northern Territory. Thousands of Aboriginal people travel to this, the largest Aboriginal sports and cultural festival in Australia. In this particular year Mr. Hawke received a petition from the Aboriginal people for recognition of their rights, and in turn he pledged the drawing up of a treaty between black and white Australia. This treaty has yet to be made.

results.title: Make it funky. Planet rock.
results.creator_credit: Don Letts, Yvonne Smith, Hugh Thompson, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Dancing in the street: a rock and roll history”.
Afro-american musicians developed their own unique style which celebrated their rich cultural heritage. The episode ‘Make it funky’ features interviews and perfomances by such legends as James Brown, Sly and the Family Stone, Stevie Wonder and Marvin Gaye. The final episode in the series ‘Planet rock’ looks at rap, hip-hop and techno and the use of computers as musical instruments which allow music to become an instant global experience. Features interviews and clips from New Order, The Beastie Boys and Public Enemy.

results.title: Make believe marriage
results.creator_credit: Robert Fuest, Evelyn Barron, Highgate Pictures and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Learning to be human”.
Follows the progress of a group of senior high school students who undertake a marriage course lasting one semester. After being arbitrarily assigned a marriage partner, the couples are required to work out a suitable budget, undertake shopping trips to price basic items and generally come to terms with differing likes and dislikes. Each “family” must also meet a crisis: a baby, a loss of job, or a prison term for theft. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Make a wish Molly
results.creator_credit: Bruce R. Schwartz, Betty L Spruill and Phoenix Film Group
results.brief_description: Molly has moved to California with her Russian Jewish parents who are proud of their heritage and culture. Molly is too young to appreciate her background and wants to be ‘normal’ like the other kids at school. She attends a friend’s birthday party but has to forgoe the cake because it’s Passover. Her friends find her clothes and hand-made present “funny”. Soon it is Molly’s birthday and her parents invent a way of preserving their heritage as well as embracing their new one. Designed for younger children, “Make a wish Molly” has something to offer everyone.
